instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no fan spin after liquid damage.
Orange light and SMC reset goes green and back to orange.

Liquid damage around <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> cleaned up.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.52v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 4.98v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.301v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 8.53v

<RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> pin1 = 3.302v - pin2 = 3.296v
<RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR> pin1 = 3.302v - pin2 = 3.030v
<RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> pin1 = 3.302v - pin2 = 3.208v
<RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> pin1 = 3.302v - pin2 = 3.296v

JTAG obviously removed, replaced the burnt LVDS connector.

I’m not sure where to go from here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0v"
No pulse at all when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is high, original Magsafe 2 charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
OMG! I've been testing with the wrong charger. Such a noob sometimes, I should have known better.

Now turns on, fans normal, CPU heats up but nothing on the screen. No backlight or screen activating

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message: Did you test external video and USB activity?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
I don't have a way to test external at the moment but it does power a USB mouse.
Tried another screen assembly also

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message: Maybe <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> issue or would that still initialise the display if that was faulty?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
On <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> I get 0v on pin 1 (<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL>) but I'm getting 3.3v on pin 2 and 3

<RESISTOR>R1431</RESISTOR> is the pull up resistor for <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> and its supposed to be 100k but tests as 82k on the board.
Do you think this might be an issue or is something pulling that down a touch while its attached to the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
I didn't ask for USB power.
Does the mouse get steady light if you disconnect/reconnect it when board is turned on?

Looks like no image, why do you search for backlight then?
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> goes high?
Check in the first 10s, if pulses at least...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
The light on the mouse I use is bright and then dims after 5 seconds. I think this is normal as it does it on my iMac just the same.
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> is 0.00v I can't see any pulses or maybe my multimeter is too slow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> is 0.00v"
You vannot get image, nor backlight.

Use bootable pendrive with Link LED; if flashes, there is USB activity 100%.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message: USB pendrive flashes a few times each time I plug it in

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message: Yes, no image, no backlight

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
Start with bootable USB connected and internal SSD removed.
The pendrive MUST flash continuously, like charging OSX...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
I've tested with two seperate USB that I know will boot. Neither of them flash continuously like it is booting the OS.

Tried with internal SSD removed also, don't think it is trying to boot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
As I imagined, no USB activity.
Your board doesn't boot, or gets stuck.
There is no reason to search for video.

Try known good BIOS...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message: Bios chip swapped but doesn't seem to have changed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

Did you swap the BIOS chip from working board?
Don't you have a programmer to write a known good (clean ME) BIOS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v

The BIOS chip was from a dropped <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (dead CPU) so the bios should be okay but I suppose it could be also faulty.

The only programmer I have is SOFI SP8 for doing bios locks on the old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>/<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> boards. I haven't programmed the bios on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> before, sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.

You should also reball SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
Tested all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors

<RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6111</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6112</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6113</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6118</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6119</RESISTOR>

<RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6115</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6116</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6117</RESISTOR>

<RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6121</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6122</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6131</RESISTOR>

<RESISTOR>R6133</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6132</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6128</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6127</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6126</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R6125</RESISTOR>

All test as schematic, can't see any issues with traces on the microscope.

Going to reball the SMC now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message: not sure if the SMC didn't survive the heat cycle or I messed it up, but I have no fan spin at the moment. SMC looks like its on perfectly under the microscope. Looks like I'll have to take it back off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
If this happened when reballed the SMC, you have a problem there now.
SMC is very resistant to heat; more likely bad solders.
Try a reflow and gently tap it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message: Okay, I'll heat it up and give it a couple of taps and little nudges. Its dancing while at reflow

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message: Nope, get green and orange light but no fan spin. I'll have to start again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
Actually.. tried one more time and got fan spin back.. I now have screen active but no backlight.
I can see it booting OSX

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
So you get image now?
Post <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM.
Did you try PRAM reset (2-3 times)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid, no fan spin but orange light  [solved]
threads.message:
Swapped out <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. (looking at the state of the LVDS connector originally, I'm not surprised it was dead) now works perfectly.

As ever [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] thank you for your help.
